body_html:
Well, then in turn you'd be dumping OpenCL 1.2 support altogether.
Which to be really honest, at least atm is the biggest selling point of all the affair.

I'm not sure I follow you here - SPIR is optional, not core, so there is nothing to say they have to support SPIR 1.2 over anything else. I believe the SYCL specification rather deliberately doesn't demand a particular IR format either. Or am I misunderstanding you?

Yes, and notice how it's still there, mentioned in the table notes.. Yet no description is currently available.
p.s. I just noticed it kind of moved inside AMD-2 now.

@rodburns could we maybe get this updated with the next release? These are all useful hints for our documentation.

With that, AFAIK you are the most (possibly only) cross-vendor library/path out there for accelerating ML/DNN.

I've always felt that we should be proud of how compatible ComputeCpp is. We'd also not have managed this without the open standards work driving this either!

body:
>Well, then in turn you'd be dumping OpenCL 1.2 support altogether.
>Which to be really honest, at least atm is the biggest selling point of all the affair.

I'm not sure I follow you here - SPIR is optional, not core, so there is nothing to say they have to support SPIR 1.2 over anything else. I believe the SYCL specification rather deliberately doesn't demand a particular IR format either. Or am I misunderstanding you?
>Yes, and notice how it's still there, mentioned in the table notes.. Yet no description is currently available.
>p.s. I just noticed it kind of moved inside AMD-2 now.

@rodburns could we maybe get this updated with the next release? These are all useful hints for our documentation.
> With that, AFAIK you are the most (possibly only) cross-vendor library/path out there for accelerating ML/DNN.

I've always felt that we should be proud of how compatible ComputeCpp is. We'd also not have managed this without the open standards work driving this either!
